Henry Lehrman https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Lehrman 0 Henry Lehrman (March 30, 1886 – November 7, 1946) was an American actor, screenwriter, director and producer. Lehrman was a very prominent figure of Hollywood's silent film era, working with such cinematic pioneers as D.W. Griffith and Mack Sennett. However, he is primarily remembered today not for his own achievements, but for three biographical facts: he had directed Charlie Chaplin's very first film, Making a Living (though Chaplin and he didn't get along); he was notoriously careless of the safety of the actors who worked for him; and he was the lover of the actress Virginia Rappe, for whose death Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle, in a highly-publicized series of trials, was accused, and later acquitted, of manslaughter. Henry_Lehrman ( March_30_,_1886 – November_7_,_1946 ) was an_American_actor , screenwriter , director_and_producer . Lehrman was a_very_prominent_figure of Hollywood 's_silent_film_era , working with such_cinematic_pioneers as D.W._Griffith and Mack_Sennett . However , he is_primarily_remembered today not for his_own_achievements , but for three_biographical_facts : he had_directed Charlie_Chaplin 's very_first film , Making a_Living_( though Chaplin and he did_n't_get along ) ; he was notoriously_careless of the_safety of the_actors who worked for him ; and he was the_lover of the_actress_Virginia_Rappe , for whose_death_Roscoe_"_Fatty_"_Arbuckle , in a_highly-publicized_series of trials , was_accused , and later_acquitted , of manslaughter .
